english_translation: Narrated from Zayd ibn Aslam who said: There was a dispute between Abu Dharr and a man from the Muslims. Abu Dharr reviled him (insulted his mother) by mentioning a slave woman he had in the days of ignorance. This reached the Prophet ﷺ, who said: Indeed in you, O Abu Dharr, is a quality of (pre-Islamic) pride. Nothing makes one better than another - black or green - until your companion is pleased with you. I set out seeking him and he saw me before I saw him. He said: Peace be upon you, O Abu Dharr. I came and greeted him and said: Forgive me. He said: May Allah forgive you. Then I came to the Prophet ﷺ and mentioned that to him and informed him that he was pleased with me and had sought forgiveness for me. I said: Forgive me, O Messenger of Allah. He said: May Allah forgive your companion. Then I said: Forgive me, O Messenger of Allah. He said: May Allah forgive your companion. I said: Forgive me, O Messenger of Allah - I do not know except that in the third time he said: Allah has forgiven you.

chainIssues: This hadith is mursal - Zayd ibn Aslam is reporting from Abu Dharr, but Zayd is from the second generation (Tabi'un) and Abu Dharr is a companion
Zayd ibn Aslam did not meet Abu Dharr (Abu Dharr died around 32 AH, Zayd was born 55 AH)
The chain is valid in terms of narrator reliability but has a chronological gap (mursal)

potential_issues.impact: Zayd ibn Aslam did not directly hear from Abu Dharr. While both narrators are reliable individually, the chronological gap creates a mursal (disconnected) hadith. However, given that Zayd ibn Aslam was known to preserve traditions accurately, this does not severely affect reliability

Topics: Incident of Abu Dharr insulting a Muslim by reviling his mother
Pride and tribal prejudice in early Islamic community
Reconciliation between disputing Muslims
Seeking forgiveness and acceptance
Prophet's ﷺ guidance on equality and humility

english_translation: Narrated from Ibn Tawus, from his father (Tawus) who said: There is no one who establishes a good Sunnah that is acted upon after him except that there will be for him a reward similar to the reward of those who act upon it, without any reduction from their reward. And whoever establishes a bad Sunnah that is acted upon after him, will have upon him a burden similar to the burden of those who act upon it, without any reduction from their burden.

The hadith is attributed to the Prophet ﷺ through Tawus (a tabi'i), creating a potential mursal issue

english_translation: Narrated from Qatadah, from Humaid ibn Hilal, from Jarir ibn Abdullah al-Bajali: A man from the Ansar came to the Prophet ﷺ with a pouch of gold that filled the space between his fingers. He said: This is in the Path of Allah. Then Abu Bakr stood and gave, then Umar stood and gave, then the Muhajirin and Ansar stood and gave. The face of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ brightened until we saw the brightness in his cheeks. Then the Prophet ﷺ said: Whoever establishes a good Sunnah in Islam that is acted upon after him will have for him similar to the reward of those who act upon it without any diminishment from their reward. Whoever establishes in Islam a bad Sunnah that is acted upon after him will have upon him a burden similar to the burden of those who act upon it without any diminishment from their burden.

english_translation: Narrated from Ibn Tawus, from his father (Tawus) who said: A man borrowed from a man one hundred dinars, or more or less. The lender said: I will not lend to you until you bring me a guarantor. The borrower said: I cannot find anyone to guarantee for me, but for you Allah is a guarantor and surety that I will repay you. So he lent to him. The lender then traveled by sea. When the time for repayment came, he was unable to travel to him, and the sea separated them. He took a piece of wood and drilled it, then placed the dinars in it, wrote a letter to him and placed it with the dinars. Then he sealed it. Then he said: O Allah, You took responsibility for me, and whoever pays the guarantor is absolved. Indeed, I am paying to you. He threw the wood into the sea, and the wind or the waves buffeted it back and forth. He said: If I had taken this wood for firewood for my family. So he took the wood. When he entered his house, he broke it and found the dinars and the letter, and it was from his companion. Time passed until his companion came and confronted him. He said: By Allah, indeed Allah knows that I have repaid you. He was silent towards him and went with him to count it. When he brought them out, he said: By Allah, indeed Allah knows that I have repaid you. He said: How did you repay? He informed him how he had done it. He said: Then Allah has repaid it for you.

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: This hadith is mursal - attributed to the Prophet ﷺ through Tawus (a tabi'i) who could not have directly heard from the Prophet ﷺ
Ibn Tawus and Tawus are both reliable narrators (thiqah thabt)
The missing link is presumably an unidentified companion between Tawus and the Prophet ﷺ

potential_issues.issue: Mursal hadith - Missing companion in chain
potential_issues.impact: The hadith is attributed to the Prophet ﷺ through Tawus (a tabi'i), but there is a missing link between them (likely a companion). While the narrators are reliable, the mursal nature weakens the chain. However, this hadith is well-documented and appears in multiple sources

Topics: Story of a loan without human guarantor but with Allah as guarantor
Divine providence and Allah's care for believers
Miraculous delivery of repayment

Incident of payment made to the sea
